questions.text:
A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife after an attempt at self-harm.
He is lethargic and drowsy but has normal vital signs. His oxygen saturation is 97% while he is breathing ambient air. His physical examination is normal except for somnolence.
Laboratory evaluation yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Sodium (mEq/liter)
140
136–145


Potassium (mEq/liter)
3.7
3.5–5.0


Chloride (mEq/liter)
108
98–106


Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
22
21–30


Glucose (mg/dL)
91
70–100


Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
14
10–20


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.4
0.8–1.3


Serum ethanol (mg/dL)
205
<10


Osmolality (mOsm/kg serum water)
345
285–295


An arterial blood-gas measurement reveals a pH of 7.35 (reference range, 7.38–7.44).
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The patient’s anion gap is normal. A normal anion gap also excludes alcoholic ketoacidosis, which is invariably associated with an elevated anion gap.

B) INCORRECT:

During metabolism of methanol and ethylene glycol, the contribution of the toxic alcohols to the osmolal gap decreases, whereas the contribution of the metabolites to the anion gap increases. Therefore, early in the course of methanol and ethylene glycol poisoning, an anion gap may be absent, but an osmolal gap is present. Late in metabolism, as with late methanol intoxication, an anion gap may exist without an osmolal gap. A normal anion gap also excludes late methanol ingestion when methanol has been metabolized to formic acid and causes an anion gap.

C) INCORRECT:

An overdose of aspirin would not account for the elevated serum osmolality in this case. However, patients who attempt to harm themselves may ingest more than one toxin. Such patients may not be able to provide a reliable history and should always be screened for other substances, especially acetaminophen, which can cause irreversible hepatotoxicity. Aspirin overdose typically causes a mixed acid-base disorder with a respiratory alkalosis and an anion-gap acidosis.

D) INCORRECT:

The patient’s anion gap is normal. Methanol and ethylene glycol ingestions are associated with an increased anion gap because they are each converted to toxic metabolites; metabolism of ethanol, isopropyl alcohol, or acetone does not cause an increased anion gap. During metabolism of methanol and ethylene glycol, the contribution of the toxic alcohols to the osmolal gap decreases, whereas the contribution of the metabolites to the anion gap increases. Therefore, early in the course of methanol and ethylene glycol poisoning, an anion gap may be absent, but an osmolal gap is present.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s serum ethanol level is above the legal limit for driving (>80 mg/dL is considered “driving under the influence” in most U.S. states) and meets the definition for ethanol intoxication (>100 mg/dL); a level >300 mg/dL is potentially fatal.

Serum osmolality can be measured directly and calculated from the sodium, glucose, and blood urea nitrogen levels. The calculated osmolality is 2 x [sodium] + [glucose/18] + [urea/2.8]. A serum osmolal gap >10 mOsm/kg occurs with ethanol intoxication or with ingestion of toxic alcohols, such as methanol, ethylene glycol, acetone, or isopropyl alcohol. Mannitol may also cause an osmolal gap.

The calculated osmolality for this patient is 2 (140) + 5 + 5 = 290 mOsm/liter, which differs from the measured osmolality of 345 mOsm/kg, such that there is an osmolal gap of 55. Given that ethanol can contribute to the osmolal gap, this patient’s high serum ethanol concentration must be considered. Clinical series suggest that the osmolal contribution of ethanol is slightly greater than predicted by its molecular weight of 46 mg/mmol, which would prompt clinicians to divide the serum ethanol level (mg/dL) by 4.6. Instead, dividing by 3.7 or 4 has been found to be more accurate. In this case, 205/3.7 = 55 mOsm/kg. Thus, the contribution of alcohol easily accounts for the osmolal gap and should explain the altered mental status.

The patient’s anion gap is normal. Methanol and ethylene glycol ingestions are associated with an increased anion gap because they are each converted to toxic metabolites; metabolism of ethanol, isopropyl alcohol, or acetone does not cause an increased anion gap. A normal anion gap also excludes alcoholic ketoacidosis, which is invariably associated with an elevated anion gap.

During metabolism of methanol and ethylene glycol, the contribution of the toxic alcohols to the osmolal gap decreases, whereas the contribution of the metabolites to the anion gap increases. Therefore, early in the course of methanol and ethylene glycol poisoning, an anion gap may be absent, but an osmolal gap is present. Late in metabolism, as with late methanol intoxication, an anion gap may exist without an osmolal gap. A normal anion gap also excludes late methanol ingestion when methanol has been metabolized to formic acid and causes an anion gap.

Key learning point: The findings of a high serum ethanol level with an osmolal gap but no anion gap is most consistent with a diagnosis of ethanol intoxication.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy with a history of well-controlled asthma and receptive and expressive speech delays is watching his father get ready for work. He is imitating him shaving and brushing his teeth. Later, the boy is found in his room, difficult to arouse and smelling of mouthwash. No trauma was witnessed, and the only medications in the house are acetaminophen, albuterol, and an antihypertensive that are locked in a medicine cabinet. There is no family history of cardiac or metabolic disorders.
In the emergency department, the patient’s temperature is 35.8C, his heart rate is 100 beats per minute, his respiratory rate is 10 breaths per minute, his blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg, and his oxygen saturation is 95% while he is breathing ambient air. He has a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 6. His pupils are 4 mm and sluggishly reactive, and his extremities are cool.
In addition to stabilizing the airway and establishing intravenous access, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this child?

choices.text: Initiate gastric decontamination with activated charcoal

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gastric decontamination is generally not recommended for ethanol intoxication because alcohol is rapidly absorbed from the gut and not adsorbed by activated charcoal.

B) CORRECT:

This 6-year-old boy has experienced ethanol intoxication. Ethanol’s presence in alcoholic beverages is widely known, but awareness of its presence in other household items (e.g., mouthwash and hand sanitizers) is more limited. Ethanol intoxication manifests differently in children than in adolescents and adults. In children, the triad of coma, hypothermia, and hypoglycemia appears once ethanol levels exceed 50 to 100 mg/dL. In adults, emotional lability, ataxia, slurred speech, and vomiting are signs of ethanol toxicity.

The approach to any patient with altered mental status should first include airway, breathing, and circulatory support. Supportive care is the mainstay of managing ethanol intoxication, including rapid evaluation for hypoglycemia and management of hypovolemia and hypothermia, if present. The hypoglycemia associated with severe ethanol intoxication is dangerous and readily remedied once recognized.

Key learning point: In a child with accidental ethanol ingestion who presents with altered mental status, a priority is to check the patient’s blood level of glucose.

C) INCORRECT:

Checking a serum ethanol level is important to confirm suspicion of ethanol intoxication and to determine severity, but it is not the most important next step to take.

D) INCORRECT:

Fomepizole, an alcohol dehydrogenase inhibitor, is recommended for methanol or ethylene glycol poisoning. Methanol toxicity causes central nervous system depression and irreversible optic changes. Ethylene glycol toxicity causes calcium oxalate crystal formation that results in hypocalcemia and nephrotoxicity.

E) INCORRECT:

Only after stabilizing the patient and gathering further history should the potential need for child protective services be considered.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by police after being found agitated and combative in a parking lot. He smells of alcohol and appears intoxicated. He is yelling incoherently, swinging his arms, and refuses to cooperate with the examination. There are no obvious signs of trauma on initial observation. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administer haloperidol intramuscularly for rapid sedation
Apply physical restraints to facilitate examination
Prepare for rapid sequence intubation due to altered mental status
Give intravenous lorazepam for immediate behavioral control

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While haloperidol is appropriate for refractory agitation in alcohol intoxication, pharmacologic intervention should not be the initial approach.

B) INCORRECT:

Physical restraints are not an appropriate initial approach to managing agitation and may escalate the situation.

C) INCORRECT:

Rapid sequence intubation is not indicated for agitation alone in alcohol intoxication. The patient's ability to yell and move indicates adequate respiratory function.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – The initial management of agitation in alcohol intoxication begins with de-escalation techniques. It is essential not to assume that agitation is caused by alcohol alone until other causes such as injury, illness, or concurrent conditions have been systematically excluded through proper assessment.

E) INCORRECT:

Although benzodiazepines can be used for refractory agitation, they should not be the first-line approach before attempting de-escalation.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious in a park. He is responsive to painful stimuli with slurred speech and appears confused. Vital signs are BP, 105/68; P, 72; R, 12; oxygen saturation, 96% on room air. His breath smells of alcohol, and he has urinary incontinence. Point-of-care glucose is 92 mg/dL. After 4 hours of observation with supportive care including thiamine supplementation, he is awake and oriented to person and place but not time. He has a steady gait but moves slowly. He states that he drinks alcohol daily and has no one to pick him up. What is the most appropriate disposition?

choices.text: Transfer to psychiatric facility for evaluation
Discharge home with follow-up instructions only
Discharge when blood alcohol concentration is below 80 mg/dL

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

There is no indication for psychiatric evaluation in this case. The patient does not present with psychosis, suicidal ideation, or other psychiatric emergencies that require immediate psychiatric facility transfer.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient has not met discharge criteria as he has incomplete cognitive recovery, impaired motor function, and no safe method of getting home. These factors indicate a continued need for medical supervision.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient requires hospital admission due to incomplete cognitive recovery (disoriented to time), impaired motor function affecting his ability to move independently, and lack of safe transportation. His history of daily alcohol use also raises concern for complications of withdrawal, which requires monitoring.

D) INCORRECT:

Blood alcohol concentration should not be used to determine discharge readiness as it correlates poorly with clinical intoxication. Clinical assessment of cognitive and motor function is more appropriate for discharge decisions.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient has incomplete cognitive recovery (not oriented to time), impaired motor function (slow movement), and no safe transportation method. Discharge without ensuring complete functional recovery and safe transport is inappropriate.
